subject: Re: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?
msgSnippet: Except: assertTrue(true) assertTrue(collection.size() == 2) assertTrue(collection.elementAt(2) = foobar) would all score the same, while the value of each
messageBody:
Except:
assertTrue(true)
assertTrue(collection.size() == 2)
assertTrue(collection.elementAt(2) = foobar)

would all score the same, while the value of each assertion is
radically different. What could such a metric tell me that I don't
already know?

Kent

--- In junit@y..., "Michael Silverstein" <msilverstein@s...> wrote:
> I don't have a strong opinion one way or another but I've seen a
number of
> appends that held up some number of tests as a metric of the
effectiveness
> of their unit testing. It would strike me that a more meaningful
metric
> would be the number of asserts, since that indicates how many
conditions
> were checked for correctness. So it is true that a unit test passes
or it
> doesn't and if it doesn't, you fix it and move on. However, if
someone is
> going to tout metrics, they should at least pick one that is as
meaningful
> as possible.
